The lanthanum dodecyl sulfate catalyst (La(DS)3) was synthesized using a solvent-free mechanical ball method and applied in the preparation of solvent-free N-heterocyclic compounds. The preparation of the La(DS)3 catalyst and the synthesis of C-N bond series compounds only require brief ball milling of the mixed material at room temperature. Various analyses such as SEM, HRTEM, XRD, AFM, FT-IR, XPS, TGA, and DFT were conducted, which showed that the catalyst material synthesized by mechanical ball milling exhibited superior catalytic activity, thermal stability, and cyclic life compared to similar materials synthesized in an aqueous phase. The solvent-free catalytic synthesis of quinoxaline, dihydroacridin-1(2H)-one, and bis(indolyl)methanes derivatives achieved excellent target yields. Furthermore, the catalyst could be reused at least seven times without a significant decrease in activity after simple treatment. The catalyst also demonstrated gram scale scaling up in the model reaction. It exhibited weak hydrophilicity and a stable network-like layered nanostructure. Graphical Abstract Keywords Mechanochemistry Solvent-free catalysis La(DS)3 catalyst Catalytic organic synthesis DFT theoretical calculation N-heterocyclic derivatives Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Mechanochemistry is increasingly being acknowledged as an environmentally friendly alternative to traditional methods, especially in solvent-free material preparation and organic synthesis [1,2]. Advantages of mechanochemical reactions include reducing solvent usage, simplifying experimental procedures, enhancing catalyst recycling efficiency, and minimizing energy consumption [3,4]. This method is believed to be in line with the principles of green chemistry and shows significant potential for solvent-free catalytic organic synthesis [5]. Over the past decade, nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compounds have emerged as a highly valuable group of scaffolds in pharmaceuticals and bioactive natural products. Among these, quinoxalines and bis(indolyl)methanes stand out as a versatile class of compounds with significant pharmacological importance, attributed to their intriguing biological activities (as shown in Fig. 1). Various catalysts have been used in the synthesis of quinoxaline and bis(indolyl)methanes derivatives, including cerium ammonium nitrate [6], Ru3(CO)12/CsOH·H2O [7], silica gel [8], Zr(OTf)4 [9], Ni(OTf)2 [10], tBuONa/DMSO [11], Ni@Co3O4 [12], metal hydrogen sulfates[13], molecular iodine [14], ionic liquid [15], MCM-41 mesoporous molecular sieves [16] , Zr(DS)4 [17], Fe(DS)3 [18], among others. However, many of these methods have drawbacks such as expensive catalysts, complex preparation processes, toxic solvents, long reaction times, harsh conditions, cumbersome post-processing, low product yield, and challenging catalyst recycling. As a result, there is a need to develop an efficient, simple, cost-effective, safe, and environmentally friendly method for the preparation of N-containing heterocyclic compounds. Kobayashi. S, et al. explored the use of Lewis acid-surfactant combination catalysts (LASCs) in aqueous organic catalytic synthesis [19–21]. The preparation method of LASCs catalyst system is simple and easy to operate, effectively solving the problems of Lewis acid decomposition in water and the inherent incompatibility between organic compounds and water. However, challenges remain in fully regenerating the catalyst with its original chemical properties, as well as in managing the significant amounts of organic waste liquid containing toxic metals and surfactants generated during de-emulsification (approximately 350 mL of SDS toxic wastewater per 2.74 mmol of the LASCs catalyst). These factors currently restrict the widespread application of this method at scale. In a separate study, Abdolkarim. Z, et al. detailed the synthesis of quinoxaline derivatives in aqueous solution at room temperature using Zr(DS)4 as a catalyst [17]. Ruby. S, et al. further contributed to the field by preparing Fe(DS)3 catalysts for the efficient synthesis of quinoxaline compounds in the aqueous phase [22]. Additionally, Hojat, V. et al. conducted a study on the synthesis of bis(indolyl)methanes catalyzed by Fe(DS)3 in water [18]. The process of catalyst preparation and synthesis is described as straightforward. However, challenges arise in the recovery of the catalyst in these applications, leading to the generation of a significant amount of toxic wastewater containing sodium dodecyl sulfate during the post-treatment phase. In response to this issue, our research group introduced a novel approach using a Lewis acid-surfactant-SiO2 combination nanocatalyst (LASSC) [23]. This catalyst was successfully employed in solid phase grinding to produce bis(indolyl)methane compounds at room temperature without the need for organic solvents. The utilization of this method not only reduces wastewater production but also enhances product yield, catalyst reusability, and addresses some of the limitations associated with the LASC catalyst. Furthermore, our group applied the LASSC catalyst in the synthesis of asymmetric bis(indolyl)methane through solvent-free solid phase grinding, yielding excellent outcomes [24]. The possibility of preparing the LASC catalyst through mechanochemical grinding under solvent-free conditions and its application to solvent-free solid-state grinding reactions is worth considering. This is because it addresses a fundamental issue in the development of green chemistry, which is to restrict or effectively reduce the generation of pollutants from the source. In this study, we successfully synthesized the La(DS)3 catalyst using a mechanochemical ball milling method and applied it to the efficient synthesis of quinoxalines and bis(indolyl)methanes derivatives without the use of solvents. This system offers several advantages. Firstly, the catalyst can be easily prepared with a simple operation and without the need for solvents. Secondly, the catalytic reaction occurs rapidly through mechanical grinding, without the involvement of solvents. Furthermore, the catalytic system allows for quantitative experiments. 2 Results and discussion To develop an environmentally friendly and energy-efficient method for synthesizing N-heterocyclic compounds of biological importance, we conducted in-situ preparation of La(DS)3 catalyst via solvent-free mechanical ball milling. This method enabled the solvent-free synthesis of nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compounds such as quinoxaline, dihydrocridin-1(2H)-one, and bis(indolyl)methane derivatives at ambient temperature. Initially focusing on quinoxaline synthesis as a model reaction, we optimized the reaction conditions using various La(DS)3 catalysts and solvent-free grinding. Through meticulous catalyst screening, we identified the optimal conditions for synthesizing compound 3a, achieving a remarkable 99 % product yield with La(DS)3 catalyst, 0.5 g NaCl grinding assistant, and 30 minutes of grinding time ( Table 1, entry 9). In the solvent-free grinding reaction, the presence of only NaCl, Al2O3, and SiO2 grinding additives resulted in a yield of the target product lower than 5 % (Table 1, entries 2–4). No products were produced when pure reaction raw materials were present (Entry 1). When SDS and NaCl were used simultaneously for the reaction, only a small amount of 3a was obtained (Entry 5). No reaction occurred in the absence of catalysts and grinding aids (Entry 1). The use of La(NO3)3·6 H2O as a catalyst led to a product yield of 75 % (Entry 6), suggesting that Lewis acid can catalyze the preparation of quinazoline. Subsequently, using La(DS)3 as the catalyst and NaCl as the grinding agent, the investigation of product yield at different reaction times revealed that 30 minutes was optimal (Entries 7–10). Further optimization of the amount of grinding aids showed that 0.5 g was the most effective (Entries 11–13). The different Lewis acid metal salts were prepared using the same method and utilized as catalysts for a model reaction (Entries 14–16). Results indicated that La(DS)3 exhibited a superior catalytic effect (Entry 12). The optimal process conditions for the solvent-free catalytic synthesis of the model reaction involved mechanically grinding the catalyst La(DS)3 for 30 minutes with the assistance of 0.5 g NaCl promoter, resulting in a product yield exceeding 99 % (Entry 12). Additionally, to assess the performance of the newly developed catalyst in this study, a scaled-up model reaction was conducted for large-scale production in grams using a ball mill, achieving nearly perfect conversion rates of raw materials and the final product (Entry 17). The newly developed La(DS)3 nanocatalyst was utilized in the synthesis of various nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compounds through mechanical ball milling, aiming to validate its efficacy for organic synthesis reactions. La(DS)3 exhibited superior activity in a model reaction, leading to its application in hydrogen transfer reactions involving o-phenylenediamine and benzoyl compounds with diverse substituents under optimized conditions. The Fig. 2 illustrates the hydrogen transfer reaction between benzoyl and different aromatic 1,2-diamine compounds (3a-3f). Notably, both electron donating and electron withdrawing groups in aromatic 1,2-diamines were found to be compatible with benzoyl groups, highlighting the tolerance of the La(DS)3 catalyst in the reaction system. Particularly, the reaction between o-phenylenediamine and benzoyl yielded a remarkable 99 % yield (3a), while other products achieved target yields exceeding 86 % (3b-3f). Similarly, reactions involving 1,2-diketone substituted with bis(4-methoxy) and o-phenylenediamine with various substituents resulted in target product yields of 90 % (3g), 89 % (3h), and 93 % (3i), respectively. Especially, the reaction of 1,2-diketones substituted with bis(4-fluoro) and o-phenylenediamine with various substituents resulted in high product yields exceeding 90 % (3j-3m), irrespective of substituent hindrance. However, the reaction between 4-nitro-phenylenediamine and benzoyl did not yield any product, even with an extended grinding reaction time of 60 min (3n). To broaden the catalyst's scope, five previously unreported solid powdered quinoxaline derivatives were synthesized, with minor adjustments in reaction conditions. The raw materials were initially heated at 50 °C for 2 min, followed by a solvent-free room temperature reaction in a ball mill for 30 minutes to achieve a target yield of 72–93 % (3o-3s). These compounds, containing abundant hydroxyl or polyfluoro substituent groups, may exhibit advantageous biological activities. The catalytic activity of the La(DS)3 catalyst was further investigated in the synthesis of quinoxaline compounds by reacting 2-bromoacetophenone compounds with aromatic 1,2-diamine. The optimization results of reaction conditions are shown in Table S1. In Fig. 3, it is demonstrated that the La(DS)3 catalyst, developed in this study, effectively catalyzes hydrogen transfer reactions between 2-bromoacetophenone and 1,2-diamine under mechanical ball milling conditions. Notably, aromatic 1,2-diamine molecules containing both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups were successfully engaged in the reaction with 2-bromoacetophenone compounds, showcasing the robust tolerance of the La(DS)3 catalyst in such reaction systems. The reaction protocol involved initial heating at 50 °C for 2 min followed by transfer to a ball mill for 30 min of grinding. This approach yielded a series of quinoxaline compounds with high yields ranging from 80 % to 90 % (5a-5m). However, 4-nitrophenylenediamine did not undergo a reaction (5n). The dihydroacridin-1(2H)-one derivative (as shown in Fig. 1) is a common chemical intermediate found in various bioactive compounds and luminescent organic materials. Due to its notable biological and pharmacological properties, it is extensively utilized in areas such as anticancer, antibacterial, and anti-inflammatory research. In this study, the solvent-free catalytic synthesis of dihydroacridin-1(2H)-one using 2-aminobenzald- ehyde and 1,3-dione compounds was explored. Optimal reaction conditions led to the production of a range of dihydroacridin-one derivatives (as shown in Table S2). Initially, the grinding reaction of 6 with cyclohexane-1,3-dione (7) was examined using a developed catalyst. The results indicated promising yields of 3,4-dihydroacridine-1(2H)-ketones ( Fig. 4; 9a-9h). Notably, reactions involving phenyl and dimethyl substituted cyclohexane-1,3-diketones (9b-9h, 81–92 %) yielded slightly lower target yields compared to reactions with cyclohexane-1,3-diketones alone (9a, 94 %), possibly due to different substituent effects. Both electron withdrawing and electron donating substituents achieved product yields above 81 %, demonstrating the catalyst's favorable substituent tolerance in this context. Next, methyl 3-oxobutanoate and ethyl 3-oxobutanoate were utilized as saturated synthesis components in the synthesis reactions with 2-aminobenzal-dehyde, leading to the production of target products with high yields ranging from 89 % to 99 %, without the formation of any by-products in a short timeframe, as shown in 9i-9j and 9k-9l, respectively. Furthermore, 2-chloromethyl-quinoline-3-carboxylate ethyl ester was employed as the reaction substrate for nucleophilic substitution reactions with 2-aminobenzaldehyde variants containing chlorine or bromine, resulting in the synthesis of biologically active halogen-substituted ethyl 2-chloromethyl-quinoline-3-carboxylate products (9m-9o) with yields of 85 %, 88 %, and 89 % respectively. Additionally, two corresponding ethyl 2-benzylquinoline-3-carboxylates were successfully synthesized in a solvent-free environment using ethyl 3-oxo-4-phenylbutanoate and halogen-substituted 2-aminobenzaldehyde as starting materials, achieving target yields of 84 % (9p) and 82 % (9q) respectively. These intermediate compounds hold potential as bioactive center groups for applications in areas such as antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and insecticides. Finally, under optimized conditions (as shown in Table S3), we explored the substrate scope for synthesizing bis(indole)methane using various aldehydes and indoles, as shown in Fig. 5. All compounds (12a-12j) with a wide range of substituents were obtained in high yields. Notably, electron withdrawing groups (12a-12f) in the indole compounds led to higher yields in a shorter reaction time compared to electron donating groups (12g-12h). Furthermore, we investigated reactions between 4-nitrobenzaldehyde and different 5-substituted indoles to broaden the range of substrates. The results demonstrated excellent yields of the target products within a short timeframe (12i-12j). In light of the exceptional catalytic performance observed, our study delved into the fundamental structural characteristics of the La(DS)3 catalyst to elucidate and comprehend the structure-activity relationship. The catalyst's structure and morphology are depicted in Fig. 6. The La(DS)3 catalyst, produced via mechanochemical grinding at room temperature, exhibits a dense nano lamellar structure with no apparent pore distribution, as illustrated in Fig. 6a. The HRTEM analysis (Fig. 6b) reveals distinct shadows with a diameter of approximately 2.0–2.5 nm on the catalyst surface, potentially attributed to exposed metal active particles. Furthermore, lattice stripes of varying sizes (0.349 nm and 0.378 nm) are evident on the catalyst surface, possibly resulting from the double-layered arrangement of SDS within the catalyst, with a head-to-head and tail-to-tail orientation. Previous literature reports a structural diameter of approximately 0.39 nm, yet the lattice dimensions observed in this study fall within the range of 0.35 nm-0.38 nm. This discrepancy suggests that catalysts synthesized through solid-state ball milling exhibit intrinsic structural variations and nanolattice sizes compared to those synthesized in aqueous phases, potentially influencing catalyst performance. Rui F. P. Pereira, et al. reported that trivalent metal hybrid materials incorporating lanthanide elements demonstrate enhanced thermal stability, electronic output, and mechanical properties compared to general composites [25]. Additionally, detailed analysis of enlarged HRTEM images (Fig. 6b) reveals dense, ordered, and symmetrical grid-like stripes, attributed to the bilayer linear structure provided by SDS in the catalyst. The unique electron distribution of lanthanide metals alters the interaction between lanthanide metals and sulfonic groups in the catalyst, resulting in the formation of a grid-like nanostructure. This nanostructure enhances catalyst stability and catalytic performance. The study shows that La(DS)3 composite materials exhibit excellent catalytic performance in various organic synthesis reactions (as shown in Figs. 2–5). Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS mapping) confirms the presence of C, La, Na, and S elements in the La(DS)3 catalyst. The structural characterization of La(DS)3 catalyst was performed using X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, as shown in Fig. 7 a. In the low-angle region of the X-ray powder diffractograms, three strong reflections were observed, with the peak at the lowest angle exhibiting the highest intensity for the catalyst. The solids displayed a reasonable degree of crystallinity, as evidenced by the relatively sharp peaks observed in the low θ region. According to Bragg's law (nλ = 2dsinθ, where θ is the diffraction half angle and λ is the incident wave wavelength), SDS exhibited three distinct sharp diffraction peaks at 3.98 nm, 2.00 nm, and 1.34 nm, respectively, while La(DS)3 also displayed three different diffraction peaks with intensities of 3.88 nm, 1.90 nm, and 1.26 nm, respectively. It is important to note that all three diffraction peaks in the La(DS)3 catalyst showed a slight red shift towards longer wavelengths. Furthermore, compared to the diffraction peaks of SDS, the catalyst's diffraction peaks were relatively broad, indicating the presence of some water within the catalyst. The interplanar spacing (d hkl ) calculated from the aforementioned diffraction peaks revealed periodicities of 3.88 nm and 3.98 nm for La(DS)3 and SDS, respectively, characteristic of lamellar arrangements consistent with the layered materials observed in the SEM image (Fig. 6a). The Fig. 7b displays the FT-IR spectra of the SDS and La(DS)3 catalyst. The La(DS)3 catalyst spectrum exhibits bands corresponding to: (i) stretching and bending vibration modes of the alkyl chain, with similar positions and relative intensities, such as 2956 cm−1 and 1378 cm−1 representing the bending and stretching vibrations of -CH3, and 2919 cm−1 and 1469 cm−1 representing the bending and stretching vibrations of -CH2 [26]; and (ii) stretching and bending vibration modes of the anionic headgroup at 463 cm−1 (symmetric OSO3-bending); 578 cm−1 and 624 cm−1 (degenerate asymmetric OSO3-bending); 850 cm−1 (symmetric S-OC stretching); 972 cm−1 (asymmetric S-OC stretching); 1087 cm−1 and 1105 cm−1 (degenerate symmetric OSO3-stretching); and 1249 cm−1, 1209 cm−1 and 1196 cm−1 (asymmetric OSO3- stretching) [27,28]. The significant shifting and splitting of both symmetric and asymmetric modes, in comparison to the SDS spectrum, was attributed to the interaction between dodecylsulfate anions and La(III) cations [28]. Consequently, the local geometry of the OSO3-site is highly asymmetric and close to C 2v symmetry [29]. The headgroup region has been shown to be particularly sensitive in detecting changes induced by positively charged species [30]. The spectrum of SDS closely resembled that reported by Sperline [31] for SDS1/8 hydrate material, where only a minor splitting of the OSO3 group was observed (C 3v symmetry [29]). The catalyst was characterized by 1H NMR, revealing chemical shifts at d = 0.84 ppm (triplet, 9H, and J = 6.7 Hz); 1.26 ppm (m, 54H); 1.46 ppm (m, 6H); and 3.66 ppm (triplet, 6H, and J = 6.7 Hz) in DMSO (Fig. 7c). In the DMSO solvent, the water signal at d = 3.37 ppm is attributed to H2O molecules from the catalyst and solvent. The 13C NMR spectrum of La(DS)3 in DMSO shows characteristic peaks of dodecylsulfate compounds at d = 14.39, 22.54, 26.00, 29.17, 29.26, 29.48, 29.50, 29.52, 29.56, 31.75, and 66.97 ppm (Fig. 7d) [29]. The SEM analysis (Fig. 6a) clearly indicates that the La(DS)3 material possesses a compact nanosheet structure. To delve deeper into the fundamental properties of the material, the atomic force microscopy (AFM) testing was performed for characterization purposes (Fig. 7e, f). The results of the experiment substantiated the presence of a two-dimensional nanosheet structure in the material, with a layer thickness of approximately 4 nm (as shown in Table. S4), aligning well with the data obtained from XRD testing (Fig. 7a). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was utilized to determine the chemical state and valence of elements in La(DS)3, as shown in Fig. 8. The narrow scans of C1s, O1s, La3d, and S2p were deconvoluted to investigate the bonding information of each element in detail. The XPS spectrum of C1s (Fig. 8(a)) exhibited binding energy peaks at 283.8 eV, 284.5 eV, and 285.2 eV, corresponding to C-H/C-C, C-C, and C-O bonds, respectively. The high-resolution spectrum of O1s (Fig. 8(b)) for the La(DS)3 catalyst revealed three main peaks at 531.6 eV, 532.4 eV, and 533.3 eV, attributed to lattice oxygen, -O-S, OS, and C-O-S bonds. The high-resolution XPS spectra of La3d of catalyst which are mainly composed of the spin-orbit splitting of La3d5/2 and La3d3/2 were illustrated in Fig. 8(c). For solid-phase grinding synthesized La(DS)3 materials, two characteristic peaks located at 836.5 eV and 839.4 eV are assigned to the La3d5/2, and two other peaks centered at 853.2 eV and 856.1 eV correspond to the La3d3/2. Its indicates the possible presence of metal La(III) ions in the form of oxides [32]. The electron-receptive nature of the rare earth metal La, particularly its 3d orbitals' tendency for multi-electron clustering, contributes to its strong adsorption selectivity and thermal stability. This also confirms the conclusion in Fig. 10(3) that the La(DS)3 catalyst has excellent catalytic and thermal stability [33]. In addition, the binding energy of La(DS)3 catalyst at 172.5 eV and 173.6 eV corresponds to the of -O-S and -OS bond(as showed in Fig. 8d), respectively. From the perspective of green chemistry, the recyclability and reusability of metal catalysis are crucial properties and potential indicators for their industrial application. To evaluate these properties, the reusability of La(DS)3 catalyst was tested in a catalytic model reaction involving o-phenylenediamine and benzoyl (as depicted in Fig. 9). Following the initial catalytic cycle, the catalyst was easily recovered from the reaction mixture through filtration, washed with ethyl acetate and ethanol (3×5 mL), and dried at 50 ˚C overnight. Subsequently, a new quinoxaline synthesis reaction was carried out using the regenerated catalyst. The results of the experiment demonstrate the stability of La(DS)3 in the catalytic reaction, as it maintained efficient catalytic activity even after being reused up to seven times without a significant decrease. In addition, by comparing the La(DS)3 catalyst system with other similar literature ( Table 2), it is evident that this catalyst offers the benefits of environmental friendliness, cost-effectiveness, and excellent stability. The in situ generation of active sites during mechanical grinding opens up numerous opportunities for its expanded use in green synthesis and catalysis. The exceptional catalytic and stable performance of catalysts is inherently linked to their stable morphology and internal structure, highlighting the crucial relationship between structure and activity. The research demonstrates the outstanding catalytic and cyclic characteristics of La(DS)3 catalysts. To further investigate, a comprehensive structural analysis was conducted on the reused catalyst, utilizing techniques such as SEM, HRTEM, TGA, FT-IR, and NMR, as illustrated in Fig. 10. Similar catalysts synthesized in an aqueous phase were also examined and compared with existing literature reports. The SEM images depicted in Fig. 10 reveal that the morphology and structure of the catalyst undergo some changes after one (1b) and five (1c) cycles, yet overall maintaining a layered structure reminiscent of the fresh catalyst (1a). After five cycles, the layered structure of the catalyst shows signs of stacking and deposition (1c). Furthermore, the catalyst synthesized in the aqueous phase exhibits a heavily stacked sheet-like structure as reported in the literature (1d), resembling the morphology of the catalyst synthesized in the solid phase after five cycles in this work. The HRTEM analysis reveals that the catalyst maintains its nanoscale structure even after 5 cycles, displaying distinct lattice stripe characteristics (as depicted in Fig. 10–2). Notably, the catalyst retains a detailed nano network structure (2a) that closely resembles the cross-linking structure of the fresh catalyst, indicating the stability of the internal structure. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of all samples in the 25–400 °C range reveals distinct weight loss trends categorized into three temperature regions, denoted as regions I, II, and III (as depicted in Fig. 10–3). The analysis of region I is very valuable, as it corresponds to weight loss from room temperature to around 160 °C, as it provides information on the release of water molecules and the formation of anhydrous complexes, with losses maintained below 5 %, while SDS can continue up to 200 °C. The absence of free water molecules within the structure of the solid phase synthesized La(DS)3 is in line with previous literature discussing the use of aqueous phase synthesis catalysts. The temperature required for organic catalytic reactions is typically below 150 °C, with La(DS)3 catalysts ensuring structural integrity and catalytic activity within this range. Both fresh and recycled catalysts exhibit excellent thermal stability in this temperature range. Between 160 °C and 200 °C (region II), both fresh and recycled catalysts experience significant weight loss, with a rate of around 45 %. This weight loss is primarily due to the release of bound water molecules within the catalyst and potential disruption of their cross-linked structure, resulting in excessive weight loss. In region III, spanning from 200 °C to 400 °C, the catalyst experiences a more modest loss of around 15 %. The data indicates that both solid-phase and aqueous phase synthesized catalysts demonstrate exceptional thermal stability, especially after 5 cycles of use, demonstrating sustained performance and ensuring efficient cycle life in the model organic reaction. The FT-IR analysis revealed that the characteristic peak positions of the catalyst synthesized through solid-state grinding (Fig. 7b) remained consistent in the fresh state and after 1 and 5 cycles (as shown in Fig. 10–4), with no significant changes in peak intensity. However, compared to the catalyst synthesized via aqueous phase (La(DS)3-water), certain infrared absorption peaks in the catalyst from this study exhibited alterations, particularly at 2925.4 cm−1 and 2851.5 cm−1, where the C-H peak intensity notably increased. Conversely, peak intensities at 801.5 cm−1 and 722.4 cm−1 decreased. These variations are attributed to differences in the preparation methods between the two catalysts. The grinding process produced a catalyst with dense structure and complete crystallinity due to high-speed molecular collisions, leading to strong interactions between the metal ion La and the sulfonic and alkyl chains in SDS. The NMR testing after 5 cycles confirmed that the catalyst maintained its structural and compositional integrity (Fig. 10–5 and 10–6). Overall, the consistent performance of the catalyst across multiple cycles supports its efficacy in organic synthesis reactions and highlights the unique properties of the La(DS)3 material synthesized through solid-state grinding. To delve deeper into the reaction mechanism of catalyst La(DS)3, density functional theory (DFT) theoretical calculations were employed in the catalytic synthesis of quinoxaline derivatives as a model system. The results of these calculations are illustrated in Fig. 11 . The entire theoretical calculation process comprises 13 steps, focusing on the formation of four transition states (TS1, TS2, TS3, TS4) which involve the combination of amino hydrogen atoms and carbonyl oxygen atoms, as well as dehydration condensation to create a ring and subsequently form carbon-nitrogen double bonds. The formation of TS1, TS2, and TS3 plays a pivotal role in determining the catalytic reaction rate, with the required free energies being 28.9 kcal/mol, 15.5 kcal/mol, and 13.8 kcal/mol, respectively. The catalyst La(DS)3 initially activates the carbon-based oxygen atoms and amino nitrogen atoms of reactants INT1 and INT3, leading to a reduction of 28.8 kcal/mol in the activation energy of the overall system and the generation of intermediate INT4. This step is pivotal for the progression of the reaction. With the assistance of La(DS)3, the nitrogen atom with lone electron pairs on the amino group of INT3 undergoes nucleophilic addition reaction with the positively charged carbon atom on the carbonyl group. This reaction occurs through the transition state TS1, accompanied by the breaking of NH bonds and the generation of O-H and C-N bonds. Next, under the action of La(DS)3, the reaction system requires 15.5 kcal/mol of energy for sustained activation, forming a transition state TS2 and promoting the binding of another hydrogen atom on the amino group of INT5 with a carbon based oxygen atom to remove a molecule of water and form a carbon nitrogen double bond, resulting in INT6. Through the action of La(DS)3, the system continues to react to form the transition state TS3. This transition state causes the remaining hydrogen and oxygen atoms in INT2 and INT1 to bind and transform into INT7, reducing the overall activation energy of the process by 23.5 kcal/mol. These results suggest that the formation of O-H bonds before INT7 necessitates energy from the catalyst La(DS)3. Subsequently, the reaction progresses to generate a transition state TS4, requiring an energy of 4.3 kcal/mol. The TS4 then rapidly converts into a more stable intermediate INT8, leading to a decrease in activation energy of the reaction by 7.4 kcal/mol. The detailed calculation data is shown in Table S5. Finally, under the action of catalyst La(DS)3, the system generates 19.2 kcal/mol of energy for the reaction, facilitating a second dehydration reaction to form the target product, thereby completing the entire reaction process. In conclusion, La(DS)3 plays a pivotal role in the catalytic reaction process by consistently lowering the activation energy and driving the progress of the reaction. Based on the theoretical calculations, the reaction mechanism of La(DS)3 catalyzed synthesis of quinoxaline derivatives was determined, as illustrated in Fig. 12 . The mechanism involves four main steps. Initially, the catalyst La(DS)3 activates the amino group of 1,2-o-phenylenediamine and the carbonyl group of benzoyl. The nitrogen atom with lone pair electrons on the amino group then undergoes a nucleophilic addition reaction with the positively charged carbon atom on the carbonyl position, resulting in the formation of an intermediate. This intermediate is further activated by La(DS)3, leading to the breaking of O-H and N-H bonds, the formation of a CN bond, and the removal of two water molecules, ultimately yielding the desired product. 3 Conclusion We have demonstrated the excellent catalytic activity and stability of La(DS)3 catalysts synthesized through mechanical ball milling. These catalysts are particularly effective in constructing C-N bond quinoxaline organic molecules with biological properties under solvent-free room temperature catalytic conditions. Through a series of characterizations that we found that La(DS)3 catalysts prepared using mechanochemical solvent-free methods exhibit a nanosheet structure and maintain certain hydrophilic properties. Notably, HRTEM analysis revealed a grid-like cross-linked structure inside the material, ensuring the catalyst's good catalytic stability even after multiple cycles of use. The La(DS)3 catalyst offers several advantages, including wide reaction universality, simple synthesis, convenient separation, high cycle life, and excellent product yield. Given the increasing focus on green chemistry research, we anticipate that this catalyst system will find widespread application in various solvent-free mechano- chemical reactions. 4 Experimental 4.1 Preparation method of La(DS)3 catalyst First, lanthanum nitrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O; 1.0 mmol) and sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS; 3.0 mmol) were weighed in a specific ratio, combined in a planetary ball milling tank, and the tank was then placed in the groove of a planetary ball mill for a continuous ball milling reaction at 600 r/min for 30 minutes. Upon completion of the reaction, the resulting mixture was transferred to a beaker, dissolved in distilled water, stirred, and washed. The white precipitate obtained was filtered using a sand core funnel, washed with a small amount of distilled water until neutral (3×5 mL), and the white solid product was collected. Subsequently, the product was dried in a vacuum drying oven at 50 °C for 48 hours to yield the final white solid powder, identified as La(DS)3. Further experimental details can be found in the electronic supplementary information (ESI). coredata.dc:description: The lanthanum dodecyl sulfate catalyst (La(DS)3) was synthesized using a solvent-free mechanical ball method and applied in the preparation of solvent-free N-heterocyclic compounds. The preparation of the La(DS)3 catalyst and the synthesis of C-N bond series compounds only require brief ball milling of the mixed material at room temperature. Various analyses such as SEM, HRTEM, XRD, AFM, FT-IR, XPS, TGA, and DFT were conducted, which showed that the catalyst material synthesized by mechanical ball milling exhibited superior catalytic activity, thermal stability, and cyclic life compared to similar materials synthesized in an aqueous phase. The solvent-free catalytic synthesis of quinoxaline, dihydroacridin-1(2H)-one, and bis(indolyl)methanes derivatives achieved excellent target yields. Furthermore, the catalyst could be reused at least seven times without a significant decrease in activity after simple treatment. The catalyst also demonstrated gram scale scaling up in the model reaction. It exhibited weak hydrophilicity and a stable network-like layered nanostructure.
